isis.stitle: INTERNATIONAL AIR SUSPENSION WITH TAPERED LEAF SPRINGS - HEIGHT CONTROL VALVE - RIDE HEIGHT ADJUSTMENT

step1.para: Verify that the center punch mark on the leveling valve capscrew is positioned toward the axle end of lever arm ( Figure 3) and that both clamps are on the inside locations (bolt head end toward the center of the vertical rod) of the rubber links.
Assure that approximately 100 psi (689.5 kPa) air pressure is available in the reservoir systems (check cab gauges).
Disconnect the vertical link from the height control valve lever.
The height adjustment is checked at the rear axle on a 4x2 chassis and the rear-rear axle on a 6x4 chassis.

step2.para: Place a straight edge on the center line of the top metal plate on the air springs ( Figure 5). Do not position the straight edge on the frame rails. Measure the distance from the bottom edge of the straight edge to the top edge of the transverse crossmember.
See RIDE HEIGHT DIMENSIONS, for the appropriate "A" dimension as illustrated in Figure 5.

step1.para: If distance is less than specified:

step2.para: Raise valve control lever and hold up until distance is correct. Center lever.
If the vehicle height is greater than in the RIDE HEIGHT DIMENSIONS, lower the valve control lever and hold down until the specified distance has been attained.

When the specified height has been attained, install two centering pins (use two No. 21, or 5/32 inch drill bits) in the valve body ( Figure 3) to maintain the lever arm in the centered position (horizontal) while installing and adjusting the vertical link to the lever arm.

step1.para: Install the vertical linkage on the height control valve lever. Verify that the vertical linkage rod is centered between the upper and lower clamps. Tighten the clamp bolt(s) and install the washer and cotter pin.

step2.para: Fine adjustment of the vertical linkage can be made by loosening the nuts on the vertical linkage rod, lower anchor and moving the nuts up or down. Tighten the nuts when completed.
